awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant University of Michigan Dearborn: Center for Pervasive Personalized Intelligence Center
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the ecosystem of computing devices (e.g. cellphones, household appliances, vehicles, etc.) connected to each other via the internet. The goal of the Pervasive Personalized Intelligence (PPI) Center is to enable the next generation of IoT systems to be more proactive and personalized without compromising security and privacy, thereby improving decision making, increasing efficiency and enabling new types of computing applications. This proposal will study the feasibility of establishing a new PPI site at the University of Michigan-Dearborn (UM-Dearborn) in collaboration with industry and the two PPI sites at the University of Colorado Boulder (CU) and Oregon State University (OSU).

Researchers at UM-Dearborn will investigate foundational research under three thrusts: Intelligent Transportation, Smart Energy, and Software Engineering Intelligence. First, under the intelligent transportation thrust, investigators will develop new algorithms and techniques enabling personalized and context-aware maneuvering of connected and automated vehicles via artificial intelligence, i.e., intelligent personalization. Second, for the smart energy thrust, investigators will create new techniques that enable novel AI-assisted personalized demand response technologies for electric prosumers. Finally, under the software engineering intelligence thrust, investigators will explore methods to help software developers to build optimized PPI applications that can be efficiently and securely deployed and evolved in cyber-physical systems.

Advances in IoT impact many facets of everyday life. The PPI Center explores research thrusts in Artificial Intelligence, Computing Systems, Programmability, Energy, Visualization, and Computer Security and Privacy that are broadly applicable beyond IoT systems to a variety of other scientific domains such as environmental science, agriculture, biology, transportation, and robotics. The research outputs will be disseminated through publications, research presentations to industry and academia, open-source code and industrial collaborations. The PPI Center is committed to broadening participation in computing through, for example, summer schools for industry engineers and K-12 outreach through partnerships with UM-Dearborn’s programs. To improve the retention of underrepresented populations, the proposed Center will work with technology associations to showcase PPI applications that help humanity.

The PPI Center will maintain a publicly accessible project repository that will store open-source code, publicly available datasets, papers and other research outputs that can be disseminated to the general public on ppicenter.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past year, we have hosted several virtual and in-person meetings with industry representatives. Initially, we scheduled a virtual meeting with prospective members to share with them the ideas of 15 OU projects matching the needs identified in the customer discovery. We have gathered more feedback during that meeting about the alignments of potential OU projects with their needs and the outcomes of the customer discovery. Following this meeting, we collected industry level of interest on an initial set of 15 projects, with 10 projects from each university. We deployed an online survey via Google form, and we used the same 5 levels of interest similar to the ones that NSF typically used in the past in the L.I.F.E. forms. We used the obtained ratings to decide which projects to present in the Plenary session at the subsequent workshop. Thus, 10 OU projects were selected out of 15 projects based on the obtained scores from the forms. The official Planning Workshop was held on April 7-8, 2022 in Rochester, Michigan at Oakland University.

At this meeting, 10 projects from OU covering all the three thrusts of Intelligent Transportation, Smart Energy and Software Engineering Intelligence. In addition, we had 20 PhD student posters from OU covering all 3 thrusts. In addition, CU and OSU presented a total of 4 current projects and 4 new proposals during that meeting along with 15 PhD student posters. These activities show already the synergy that exists between the sites even at this stage as we are working as one center. We analyzed the formal feedback from the feedback form responses (similar to LIFE) to explore which projects held significant interest for the companies in attendance. Participants who selected either ?Very Interested?, ?Interested? or ?Interested with Change?, indicated their positive interest in a project. Based on our analysis of the responses, we grouped projects into three categories: High (75% - 100%), Medium (50% - 74%) and Low (0% - 49%) interest. The results indicate that six of ten OSU projects were of either High or Medium interest to the companies. Based on the results of the planning meetings, subsequent discussions with several industry members, and the existing IAB members and industry members that provided letters for the OU site respectively, we selected 6 OU projects based on the high levels of interest and the points system of the IAB. Each existing or future full member company allocated 100 points across projects based on their interests. We found during the IAB discussions that the interest level percentages were consistent with the number of points distributed by the industry members. 

The prospective industry members also told us at the Planning Workshop to have a tighter focus and theme on projects pursued. We considered and have reduced our focus only 3 major thrusts (intelligent transportation, smart energy and software engineering intelligence), reducing the number of initial projects accordingly. As added members join and more funds are available, we will review with our members whether the interest and relevance of the next tier of projects should be funded or if some of the ideas/areas discussed during the workshop session deserve further development into projects that would be of greater value and relevance to the companies. We have conducted discovery visits with executives from several companies, and found alignment between their needs and our expertise. 


Last Modified: 08/21/2023
Modified by: Marouane Kessentini
